div.p: RBESTKNOWNWORK is an element belonging to the RECEPTION aspect of entries, though available anywhere in the WRITING section. It identifies the single work whose reputation exceeds others, according to external criteria (best known in literary circles), and can occur once per genre for some writers. It encloses a statement, not just a title (which is highly desirable here). It should be placed in a CHRONSTRUCT if that fits the sense, and should normally not be used in a SHORTPROSE if there is more than one chronStruct in the Div2.

div.codeblock: <RBESTKNOWNWORK>Anne Grant's best known work today (though it is known without her name) must be “Oh where, tell me where, is your Highland laddie gone.”</RBESTKNOWNWORK>
<RBESTKNOWNWORKk>Anne Barnard's “Auld Robin Gray” always enjoyed great popularity.</RBESTKNOWNWORK>

div.p: Black Beauty and Little Black Sambo are best-known works. Woolf's To The Lighthouse would be her best-known work while The Waves is a landmark text for signalling a major shift in writing style. A work can be both a best known work and a landmark text: Uncle Tom's Cabin, for instance. The landmark effect can be either social or literary. See LANDMARKTEXT. N.b. use of this tag puts any associated CHRONSTRUCT among the MILESTONES of this entry.
Question: How can I distinguish a best-known text from a Landmark Text?
Answer: See discussion in Practice Issues and see LANDMARKTEXT.
